answers.author: Tom Nosack
answers.text:
Of the measures we have tried, we found that a combination of basic workload measures (how much are you doing) and customer feedback scores (how well are you meeting customer needs) on internal surveys seems to work best.
We conduct a support services survey every two years (half the city support services each year) that queries on perception of timeliness, quality, and overall satisfaction and includes an opportunity for comments. 
A key to our success seems to be sharing the unabridged anonymous results in a timely manner.
We can compare to our past performance readily and it has been very useful to prompt change.  Comparing to others is another matter, and always allows for the argument "we are not comparable organizations".  It’s hard to make the same case when comparing to your own past performance.
